Award.AwardTitle: Nanocrystalline Metals and Thin Films: Quantized Plasticity, Internal Stress, and Grain Boundary Strength
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The proposed research aims to understand unusual characteristics of nanocrystalline metals through study of the underlying physics of deformation. This is accomplished by developing a new continuum description called quantized crystal plasticity and informing it with results from atomistic simulations and mechanical testing. The atomistic studies achieve this by measuring distributions of critical strength to trigger slip events. They also explore fundamental descriptions of the local features of grain boundaries that control dislocation absorption, repulsion, and nucleation. In this sense, two scales of simulation?continuum and atomistic?are coupled. The informed quantized crystal plasticity model can address experimentally relevant sample sizes and strain rates that are not possible with atomistic simulations. Specifically, the model is coupled to tensile experiments to study stress-assisted grain growth and the effect of bimodal grain size distributions on nc ductility. There are two primary expected technical outcomes of this work. The first is a fundamental description of the distribution of critical strengths and distribution of internal stress state in nanocrystalline metals. This includes an understanding of how these distributions evolve with macroscopic deformation. The second is a finite element based model that captures these features, and permits the prediction of the mechanical response of nanocrystalline metals to various stress or deformation paths. These outcomes provide a basis for structure-mechanical property relations for nanocrystalline metals.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Nanocrystalline metals embody an extreme strategy to make a high strength metal?namely to shrink the size of individual crystals to only a few hundred atoms across. This can reduce or eliminate defects that traditionally weaken metals and also introduce barriers that strengthen the metal. Indeed, nanocrystalline metals show promise in terms of extraordinary resistance to yielding, large fracture energy at low temperature, and improved resistance to failure under oscillating loads (fatigue). The proposed work will team researchers from US and international institutions to understand the fundamental strengthening processes. A key outcome is a computational tool to predict the mechanical properties of nanocrystalline metals based on their underlying structure. This enables optimization of the performance of such materials. Two graduate students will be trained in the use of advanced computational and experimental techniques. They will also assist in the development, implementation, and refinement of project-based learning modules for a new Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) secondary school. A spin off of this effort is novel, web-based interfaces to improve comprehension of materials engineering concepts, and the anticipated involvement of students from under-represented groups.

Institution.Name: Ohio State University Research Foundation -DO NOT USE

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanocrystalline Metals: This project investigated the origin of the unique mechanical properties of Ni, comprised of numerous crystals (grains) of dimension ~10 to 30 nm.
Intellectual Merit: The work produced a finite element simulation technique called quantized crystal plasticity. Combined with x-ray diffraction experiments, the work showed that nanocrystalline Ni has a wide distribution of critical stress to trigger an internal slip event within a crystal, compared to conventional grain size Ni. This feature provides nanocrystalline Ni with extraordinary strength that is achieved in a gradual fashion as the Ni is deformed under load. It also showed that nanocrystalline metals can have a wide variety of deformation behavior, depending on the prior deformation put into the material.

Nanoscale Metal Layered Composites: The project also studied the mechanical response of nanoscale composites comprised of alternating layers of Cu and Ni.
Intellectual Merit: A nanoscale composite with record high hardness (resistance to permanent deformation) was made by varying the relative thickness of the Cu and Ni layers. First-ever tests to determine the strain rate sensitivity, energy of dislocation defects at interfaces, and the stress-strain response of embedded nanoscale layers within the composite were made. The results showed that nanoscale layers of Cu and Ni can achieve comparable strengths to nanocrystalline counterparts, even though only one dimension (layer thickness) is constrained to the nanometer scale. They also demonstrated unusual loading-unloading characteristics, where normally "permanent" deformation can reverse in such materials, due to the organized, structured nature of internal defects and interfaces in the material. 

Broader Impacts:

Education: The project also produced two PhD students, provided two undergraduate students with research experiences during summer periods, and supported high school student interns.

National and International Collaborations: The project fostered interaction with the Center for Integrated Nanotechnologies at Los Alamos National Laboratory, where the multilayer thin films were produced. Research ties were also developed with the Center for Nanomechanical Systems at Oak Ridge National Laboratory, were a 4-axis x-ray diffraction apparatus with a built-in heating stage was used to study the response of confined Cu and Ni layers within a composite. International collaborations included the Materials Science and Simulations Group at the Paul Scherrer Institute (Switzerland), which furnished key information about the internal deformation mechanisms in nanocrystalline metals, using molecular dynamics simulations. The PSI group also provided x-ray diffraction data on the internal stress in nanocrystalline Ni, following deformation. International collaborations were also developed with the Institute of Materials Physics at the University of Gottingen (Germany), where nanoscale composites of amorphous (non crystalline) and crystalline layers are studied.


Last Modified: 11/26/2013
Modified by: Peter M Anderson

Combined with x-ray diffraction experiments, the work showed that nanocrystalline Ni has a wide distribution of critical stress to trigger an internal slip event within a crystal, compared to conventional grain size Ni. It also showed that nanocrystalline metals can have a wide variety of deformation behavior, depending on the prior deformation put into the material. They also demonstrated unusual loading-unloading characteristics, where normally "permanent" deformation can reverse in such materials, due to the organized, structured nature of internal defects and interfaces in the material. International collaborations included the Materials Science and Simulations Group at the Paul Scherrer Institute (Switzerland), which furnished key information about the internal deformation mechanisms in nanocrystalline metals, using molecular dynamics simulations. International collaborations were also developed with the Institute of Materials Physics at the University of Gottingen (Germany), where nanoscale composites of amorphous (non crystalline) and crystalline layers are studied.
